title: 113_hr4802
content: The Act titled "Gerardo Hernandez Airport Security Act of 2014" defines key terms like Assistant Secretary and Administration, related to airport security incidents response. The Assistant Secretary, in consultation with FEMA, conducts outreach to airports to ensure they have security incident response plans in place, including for active shooters and terrorism. Plans may include evacuation strategies and unified command establishment. The plan for establishing a unified command at airports includes staging areas for non-airport-specific law enforcement and fire response, regular testing of communications equipment, evaluation of emergency call procedures, communication methods with travelers, projected law enforcement response timeframes, and joint exercises with stakeholders. The Assistant Secretary will report to Congress on the findings from outreach to airports regarding their preparedness to respond to security incidents, including active shooters and acts of terrorism, within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include an analysis of airports' capabilities to handle incidents targeting passenger-screening checkpoints. SEC. 4. The Assistant Secretary will identify and share best practices for security incident planning at airports. SEC. 5. Screening personnel must participate in active shooter training exercises, certified annually. SEC. 6. Reimbursable agreements will be established. SEC. 6. The Assistant Secretary will analyze cost savings to increase funding for checkpoint screening law enforcement support agreements over 5 years. SEC. 7. No additional funds authorized for this Act, to be carried out using existing amounts. SEC. 8. Interoperability review. SEC. 8. INTEROPERABILITY REVIEW. Within 90 days of enactment, the Assistant Secretary will review the communications capabilities of law enforcement, fire, and medical personnel at all US airports for responding to security incidents. A report on the findings will be submitted to relevant congressional committees within 30 days of completion. Passed the House of Representatives on July 22, 2014. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
